headline.main: The Old, The Dream And Nolan

results.snippet: OLD athletes chasing the dying sun are seen as sad by some. Not by these eyes.    I rooted for Jim Palmer, hamstring and all, defused fastball and all, to make it. He didn't.
results.lead_paragraph: OLD athletes chasing the dying sun are seen as sad by some. Not by these eyes. I rooted for Jim Palmer, hamstring and all, defused fastball and all, to make it. He didn't.

headline.main: Shuttle Arm Dangles 'Star Wars' Satellite for Tests

results.snippet: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery dangled a "Star Wars" research satellite on the end of the shuttle's outstretched mechanical arm today for 24 hours of tests.    As the Discovery whirled around the Earth at 17,500 miles an hour,...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery dangled a "Star Wars" research satellite on the end of the shuttle's outstretched mechanical arm today for 24 hours of tests. As the Discovery whirled around the Earth at 17,500 miles an hour, the satellitee's infrared sensors and television cameras focused on the planet and atmospheric light, or aurora. A camera on the shuttle's 50-foot arm also occasionally displayed scenes of Earth, 160 miles below the shuttle.

results.snippet: Astronauts on the space shuttle Discovery succeeded in getting data from three scientific instruments to Earth today after splicing wires and rearranging cables in a 97-step salvage operation.    The electrical repair job was a final attempt to...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts on the space shuttle Discovery succeeded in getting data from three scientific instruments to Earth today after splicing wires and rearranging cables in a 97-step salvage operation. The electrical repair job was a final attempt to retrieve information from the instruments, which became virtually useless after their data recorders failed shortly after the shuttle was launched a week ago. Mission Control now hopes to obtain about half of the information that was initially sought.

results.snippet: "It's easy to tell which kids are the Americans and which are not," reports a young woman who has spent her post-college year teaching and traveling in Europe. "Look at the signs on their clothes. The Americans don't advertise."    The...
results.lead_paragraph: "It's easy to tell which kids are the Americans and which are not," reports a young woman who has spent her post-college year teaching and traveling in Europe. "Look at the signs on their clothes. The Americans don't advertise." The non-Americans, however, flaunt hats, sweaters, sweatshirts and jackets emblazoned with colorful slogans written in English. Well, English with a certain spin on it.

results.snippet: Forty-four brine shrimp were hatched on the space shuttle Atlantis in April, making them among the first animals ever born in space.   Biologists from Kansas State University and the University of Nebraska at Lincoln devised the experiment to study...
results.lead_paragraph: Forty-four brine shrimp were hatched on the space shuttle Atlantis in April, making them among the first animals ever born in space. Biologists from Kansas State University and the University of Nebraska at Lincoln devised the experiment to study how animals are born and grow without gravity. Five shrimp were still alive when the shuttle landed. The biologists said the rest may have died from insufficient oxygen or nutrients in their water.

headline.main: First Briton in Space Goes Aloft With 2 Astronauts on Soviet Craft

results.snippet: A 27-year-old chemist today became the first Briton in space when she and two Soviet astronauts blasted off here aboard a spacecraft on an eight-day mission.   Helen Sharman, accompanied by Anatoly Artsebarsky and Sergei Krikalyov, lifted off in a...
results.lead_paragraph: A 27-year-old chemist today became the first Briton in space when she and two Soviet astronauts blasted off here aboard a spacecraft on an eight-day mission. Helen Sharman, accompanied by Anatoly Artsebarsky and Sergei Krikalyov, lifted off in a Soyuz TM-12 craft from the Baikonur space center in Soviet Central Asia.

headline.main: Station Loss Called Peril To America

results.snippet: The loss of the space station program, threatened by budget problems in Congress, would scuttle the United States manned space program and jeopardize relations with other nations investing in the project, the space agency's senior space flight...
results.lead_paragraph: The loss of the space station program, threatened by budget problems in Congress, would scuttle the United States manned space program and jeopardize relations with other nations investing in the project, the space agency's senior space flight official said today. The official, William B. Lenoir, an associate administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said the agency was surprised last week when a key House Appropriations subcommittee cut all but $100 million from the agency's $2 billion space station request for next year.

headline.main: Shuttle's Next Mission: Better Health in Space

results.snippet: In the 30 years humans have been venturing into space, their wonder at soaring into the heavens has been tempered by the problems their earth-born bodies have in this alien environment.   To better understand these problems, the space shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: In the 30 years humans have been venturing into space, their wonder at soaring into the heavens has been tempered by the problems their earth-born bodies have in this alien environment. To better understand these problems, the space shuttle Columbia is scheduled to lift off Wednesday on a medical mission. In one key experiment, an astronaut will go through liftoff with a tube threaded through a vein into blood vessels near his heart. The test will monitor blood pressure and changes in blood vessels around the heart during the stress of takeoff and the first few hours of weightlessness in space.

headline.main: Launching by Soviets Succeeds, but Advertising Plan Fails

results.snippet: Britain and the Soviet Union are apparently better at outer space than at advertising space.   A Soyuz TM-12 spacecraft launched on Friday from Soviet Central Asia carried into orbit two Soviet astronauts and Helen Sharman, a 27-year-old chemist...
results.lead_paragraph: Britain and the Soviet Union are apparently better at outer space than at advertising space. A Soyuz TM-12 spacecraft launched on Friday from Soviet Central Asia carried into orbit two Soviet astronauts and Helen Sharman, a 27-year-old chemist and Britain's first astronaut. But the craft, which docked yesterday with the Soviet Union's Mir space station and is to return to earth next Sunday, did not carry the millions of dollars worth of Western advertisements that were originally planned to make the mission profitable for the Soviet Union.

results.snippet: MARKETS    The S.E.C. took the first big step toward round-the-clock trading on the New York Stock Exchange, approving a request to extend Big Board hours beyond 4 P.M. The extension of trading to 5 P.M. for individual stocks and 5:15 for "baskets"...
results.lead_paragraph: MARKETS The S.E.C. took the first big step toward round-the-clock trading on the New York Stock Exchange, approving a request to extend Big Board hours beyond 4 P.M. The extension of trading to 5 P.M. for individual stocks and 5:15 for "baskets" of securities is the first phase in the exchange's plan to offer 24-hour trading. [ Page A1. ] Stock trading dropped to its slowest pace of the year. The Dow industrials edged ahead 5.59 points, to 2,892.22. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed. [ D14. ]

headline.main: London Journal; First Briton in Space, but Barely in Fame's Orbit

results.snippet: When Helen Sharman of Sheffield roared into space atop a Soviet rocketship last Saturday, The Observer of London bannered the moment the next day with a front-page headline that read, "Women From Mars Is First Briton in Space."   The reference to...
results.lead_paragraph: When Helen Sharman of Sheffield roared into space atop a Soviet rocketship last Saturday, The Observer of London bannered the moment the next day with a front-page headline that read, "Women From Mars Is First Briton in Space." The reference to Mars, however, had nothing to do with Miss Sharman's new life in outer space. Rather, The Observer, like other British papers, has been playing in recent months on Miss Sharman's former employment at the Mars candy bar factory outside London.

headline.main: After 3 Terms in Senate, Garn of Utah Is Leaving

results.snippet: Senator Jake Garn, the Utah Republican who six years ago became the first incumbent member of Congress to fly in space, said today that he would relinquish his seat next year to spend more time with his family.   In an announcement made to his...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator Jake Garn, the Utah Republican who six years ago became the first incumbent member of Congress to fly in space, said today that he would relinquish his seat next year to spend more time with his family. In an announcement made to his supporters in Salt Lake City and also released here, Mr. Garn said his decision not to seek election to a fourth term had been a difficult one.

headline.main: Stoves to Salt Shakers, Basics of an Ad Campaign

results.snippet: "YOU always come back to the basics" is the slogan that has been running with print advertisements for Jim Beam whisky since the fall of 1989.    "We've done over 30 executions of the ad," using the same slogan with different illustrations, said...
results.lead_paragraph: "YOU always come back to the basics" is the slogan that has been running with print advertisements for Jim Beam whisky since the fall of 1989. "We've done over 30 executions of the ad," using the same slogan with different illustrations, said Robert Barrie, a creative director for the Minneapolis agency Fallon McElligott , which created the series.

results.snippet: An article yesterday about Senator Jake Garn of Utah described the record of space flight by members of Congress incorrectly in some copies. Mr. Garn was the first incumbent member of Congress to fly in space, not the only one. Representative Bill...
results.lead_paragraph: An article yesterday about Senator Jake Garn of Utah described the record of space flight by members of Congress incorrectly in some copies. Mr. Garn was the first incumbent member of Congress to fly in space, not the only one. Representative Bill Nelson of Florida was a member of the crew of the space shuttle Columbia that was launched on Jan. 12, 1986. Senator John Glenn of Ohio was an astronaut before his election.

results.snippet: A chart on Saturday listing women who have flown on space missions, with an article about the first Briton in space, omitted an American astronaut. She is Ellen Baker, who flew on the space shuttle in October 1989.
results.lead_paragraph: A chart on Saturday listing women who have flown on space missions, with an article about the first Briton in space, omitted an American astronaut. She is Ellen Baker, who flew on the space shuttle in October 1989.
